It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire to pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has actually lived experiences as recorded. It is possible for the questions here will not apply to your experiences or your views. The best of pioneer experiences are not expressed in writing. Blank spaces, "N/A," are given at the end of each question here will not apply to your experiences or your views.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1920, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer era whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets of paper for a separate questionnaire.

PIONEER QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. GENERAL INFORMATION

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no single person can answer all questions. It is necessary to consider the experiences of others.

Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

The questions are given generally, and answers should be given in detail where possible.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1934, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

B. OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Saskatchewan Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, and would be willing to do so, please get a copy and have it sent to us.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

C. INTERPRETATION OF QUESTIONNAIRES

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of the province. Please return your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: N. Scott Branscombe
2. Your address: Wadena, Sask.
3. Date: May 26, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Grand Lake, N.B.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Emery Branscombe, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August 1903
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: Centerville, N.B., also Melita, Man.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). I was 21
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To see the great Western plains & to work in the harvest fields
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). Reading about it & talking about it to people who had previously been there.
Branscombe, N. Scott
Wadena

To Sask. - August, 1903.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: N. Scott
2. Your address: Wadena, Sask.
3. Date: August 1903
4. Where were you born? (Give name or place and county) Grand Forks of 1888
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Henry Branscombe, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) August 1903
7. Mention any other places you have lived in Saskatchewan, giving date of arrival and purpose of visit. (If you have lived elsewhere, mention that fact.)
   Centerville 1903 also Walter Quan.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child.")
   It was in my teens, etc.). June 21
9. What were your reasons for coming West? To see the great Western plains & to work in the harvest fields

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    Reading about it by talking about it. To people who had previously been there.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They all thought it would be a wonderful experience but my father queried about me going west & leaving the old home.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
I traveled alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
All the way by rail.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
I traveled west on the hardest expedition. The car that I happened to get into was quiet & we had a very lovely trip. But the car just ahead of us was quite different. Every window & door broken out. The ring leaders were finally taken to jail & four of them. I never heard of them again.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
I stayed at Mr. Brooks' Boarding House at Melita, Man.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
At Wadena, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
I have lived in Wadena since 1904.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
Before coming to Western Canada I worked on my Father's farm. After I came here I have farmed most of the time. For the last ten years I have taken care of the school here at Wadena.
12. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They all thought it would be a wonderful experience for my family during about going country living in old home.

13. What means of transportation did you use? All the way by rail.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.) I traveled westward on the Kansas Expression. The ear that happened to get into very great + we had a very lonely trip. But the car stopped + we were quite off course. Many wonders & com

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? I stayed at Mr. Brodie's boarding house at Qu'Appelle, Qu'Appelle.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? At Waddington.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. I have lived in Waddington since 1904.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Before coming to Western Canada I worked as a farm hand. After coming here I have learned to become a farmer. I have been working on the land for many years now.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
About four times a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
I was married to Martha L Orchard in 1912 at Fredericton N.B.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
Yes, my brother George Branscombe.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
My Father Mother two Brothers & sister came west in 1914. Built a store (general merchandise) & lived at Kelvington Sask.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
Yes, driving open I never shall forget. The wagon we had swabbed from side to side on the side hills it really had a bad start. We started to break with a one handled plough in the excitement I ploughing my cap off it went the remainder of the summer with a red handkerchief over my head. I remember well the mosquitoes bit right through. This is very little of what did happen.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
We travelled very little in the early days except to go to church which was held in the neighbour's house, & to go to Wadena for supplies which was 15 miles. This was done by ox team & we usually made it in a day. You may be sure the day was really fast.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About twice a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

In 1913 at Greenlawn, Ontario.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

Yes, my brother George Branscombe.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My father brought two brothers and myself to a farm at Lubington, York.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Claiming open range I never shall forget.

The wagons we had loaded from side to side on the side hills it really took a bad start.

We started to build with our hands they thought in 24 feet wide plowed in my corn field.

Next summer we had plenty of rain.

Last year my head frequently went through the snow.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

We traveled every little in the early days.

We went to church which was held in the neighboring town, 4 to 50 to Wadena.

For supplies which were miles this way down by the river actually made it in a day, so you may be sure the trip was really fast.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Do you remember about 1909 and Herb Prince Liberal member owned?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? At Wadena 18 miles from the homestead.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.). I continued to trade here.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? About once every month.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? I don't think this habit was formed while I was on the farm even with horses it was a long trip until the car came.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period. I started to buy through the mail order catalogue about 1915. Clothing, a very small percentage, perhaps 5%. The percentage is much more now than it was in the pioneer days.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? In 1950, the government telephone.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? I came here first with the intention of making a fortune. I didn't, however, liked it here & stayed.

34. Do you have any other information about the history of your community?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Very few moved; tired of watching.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Not very many moved away perhaps three or four. Some did return.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

None have held any public office.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

None had done so.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The present town of Wadena got its name from early settlers here & were from the town of Wadena in Minnesota. The school was called Duck Creek. From a creek nearby. This creek was near my homestead in 1828-36-1/2. This creek was usually full of ducks in the early days.

The creek was usually filled up during the

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I have 3 children grown up now. My oldest lives at Val-Dor & is teaching high school there. Her name now is Pearl Crowell. Second daughter is secretary in the Firestone rubber plant at Hamilton, name Madelyn Branscomb. My son Emery Branscomb is at University in Toronto. Taking a cord in dentistry.
